author: Staff Reporter
text:
The West Bengal leadership of the Revolutionary Socialist Party (RSP) — a key Left Front constituent — is caught in a dilemma over the Left-Congress seat-sharing as the new foe-turned-friend of the alliance is contesting in nine of the traditional constituencies of the party.

While the Congress’s decision has left the RSP leadership fuming, the party is unable to act independent of the Left Front.

Addressing presspersons on Tuesday, RSP State secretary Kshiti Goswami clearly reflected his party’s dilemma. “We are disciplined soldiers of the Left Front and will go by the Front’s decision,” he said. However, he added: “We have been as flexible as possible and cannot do anything more ... it’s a question of our political existence.”

Congress flayed

He criticised State Congress president Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury for accusing the RSP of “throwing a spanner” in the seat-sharing negotiations. “Mr. Chowdhury’s remarks are unfortunate and not conducive to the ongoing Left-Congress negotiations,” said Mr. Goswami. Earlier Mr. Chowdhury had said: “CPI(M) will have to accommodate them [the Front allies]. It is not our responsibility.”

In a bid to send a message to the CPI(M) leadership, which strongly advocates the Left-Congress tie up, Mr. Goswami described the alliance as the “most temporary arrangement for votes”.

“It is just to ensure that anti-Trinamool votes are not divided,” he said.
title: RSP caught in a dilemma in Bengal
